Hey guys, I take it as some people in here have tried to query the phone for given name, family name and phone number in the same projection? I have a custom adapter and it works fine when I query for display name and number, it fetches them and displays them in a nice way in my list. However when I query for the other 3 mentioned earlier I get a very annoying bug - It displays the number as a separate line in an own element in the list and the element under is containing the name, sometimes it even fetches the given name and family name twice. Any suggestions?

Hi,
I'm trying to create a local proxy that intercepts http requests, forward them to webview, where they are manipulated and loaded back to the app.
I used NanoHTTPD, but when overriding the Response method I need to return a stream within the same function, but if I go through the webview the response is returned async through a different method. Anyone has experience with that?
are you just trying to manipulate the responses back to the app?

so for example instead of the app doing <http://www.domain.com/api|www.domain.com/api>, it's doing localhost:8080?url=<http://www.domain.com/api|www.domain.com/api>
That's intercepted in NanoHTTPD, and the url passed to webview to do an xhr, manipulate it and respond with the manipulated response
responds back to java
<@U2ZNN76JV> Does that make sense?
hey yea
sorry i thought you were having issues with something i recently went through
which was returning test responses after network requests in the app
for which i used Charles/Fiddler proxies
not sure how to go about your issue though :disappointed:

attachments.title: Getting a Result from an Activity | Android Developers
attachments.text: Starting another activity doesn&#39;t have to be one-way. You can also start another activity and receive a result back. To receive a result, call startActivityForResult() (instead of startActivity()). For example, your app can start a camera app and …
attachments.fallback: Getting a Result from an Activity | Android Developers

and try pasting that into the second activity
<https://developer.android.com/guide/components/tasks-and-back-stack.html> preserves previous activity data, etc., and does the back navigation for you automagically

attachments.title: Tasks and Back Stack | Android Developers
attachments.text: An application usually contains multiple activities . Each activity should be designed around a specific kind of action the user can perform and can start other activities. For example, an email application might have one activity to show a list of new…
attachments.fallback: Tasks and Back Stack | Android Developers

<@U2Z7P9VA4> I'm assuming you don't have a toolbar. Try changing this `Theme.AppCompat.Light.DarkActionBar` to `Theme.AppCompat.Light`. That should make the "actionbar" text black as you desire
<@U1HM4MPLJ> seems like he does have a toolbar, he mentioned having a hamburger menu
android studio usually makes a navigation view, coordinatorlayout and toolbar for you
brb lunch
if I copy the toolbar into my second activity’s layout, now I get two toolbars, one with the white font and back arrow, the other is empty
<@U1HM4MPLJ> yeah, that did it
Ah. Then you probably want to change this `ThemeOverlay.AppCompat.Dark.ActionBar` to `ThemeOverlay.AppCompat.ActionBar` in `AppBarOverlay`
I wondered if the white font was embedded in the “Dark” action bar, but I’m also surprised they don’t provide a means to override those styles
And ensure that you apply `android:theme="@style/AppBarOverlay"` on the toolbar
Oh. Great!

what would the popupTheme be used for? dialogs?

Try this for the toolbar theme
```
<style name="ToolbarTheme" parent="ThemeOverlay.AppCompat.Light" />
```
Popup theme is used for the toolbar overflow menu
